question: No, no trouble, Harry, be right down. Son of a bitch.
answer: Where's that cheery face we've come to know and love?

question: You call me in on my day off because some idiots have broken into local Democratic Headquarters--tell me, Harry, why should I be smiling?
answer: As usual, that keen mind of yours has pegged the situation perfectly. Except it wasn't local Democratic Headquarters, it was National Democratic Headquarters-- --and these weren't just any idiots, these were special idiots, seeing as when they were arrested at 2:30 this morning, they were all wearing business suits and Playtex gloves and were carrying-- --a walkie-talkie, forty rolls of film, cameras, lock picks, pen-sized tear gas guns, plus various bugging devices. Not to mention over two thousand dollars, mostly in sequenced hundred dollar bills.

question: Preliminary hearing at Superior Courthouse?
answer: Two o'clock, work the phones 'til you go.

question: (to the COUNSEL'S Mr. Caddy? My name's Bob Woodward, I'm from the Post and I wanted to ask about how you happened to come on this case--
answer: --I'm not here.

question: Douglas Caddy, the attorney of record, when questioned about his presence in the courtroom, denied he was in the courtroom, "I'm not here," Mr. Caddy said.
answer: Clearly, I am here, but only as an individual, I'm not the attorney of record. Mr. Rafferty has that position. Whatever you want, you'll have to get from him, I have nothing more to say.

question: Mr. Rafferty was very helpful. Four Cuban-Americans and this other man, James McCord.
answer: Look, I told you inside--

question: --you have nothing more to say, I understand that. What I don't understand is how you got here.
answer: I assure you, there's nothing mysterious involved.

question: Probably you're right, but a little while ago, I was talking to a couple of lawyers who'd been assigned to represent the burglars.
answer: So?

question: Well, they never would have been assigned if anyone had known the burglars had arranged for their own counsel. And that could only mean the burglars didn't arrange for their own counsel--they never even made a phone call. So if they didn't ask for you to be here, how did you know to come? Did you know to come because one of the other men involved in the break- in called you?
answer: There is no reason to assume other people were involved.

question: Your clients were arrested with a walkie-talkie; they didn't need that to talk among themselves.
answer: They are not my clients.

question: You're a lawyer and you're here--
answer: --I met one of the defendants, Mr. Barker, at a social occasion once-- --I have nothing more to say.

question: A Miami social occasion? Mr. Rafferty told me the Cubans were from Miami.
answer: Barker's wife called me at three this morning; her husband apparently had told her to call if he hadn't called her by then.

question: It was really nice of you to come, since you'd only met him once.
answer: Are you implying you don't believe me?

question: I have nothing more to say.
answer: You don't mind getting on people's nerves, do you?

question: Will you please state your professions. Anti-Communists? That, sir, is not your average occupation. Your name, please.
answer: James McCord.

question: Will you step forward, sir. And what is your occupation, Mr. McCord?
answer: Security consultant.

question: Where?
answer: Government. Recently retired.

question: Where in government?
answer: ...Central... Intelligence... Agency...

question: Where?
answer: The C.I.A.

question: Don't know; who the hell's Howard Hunt? It's probably nothing but check it out. Just go easy, it could be crazy Cubans.
answer: Anything?

question: Woodward's onto a new wrinkle with the break-in thing--absolute page one stuff--
answer: --in other words, you got nothing, you're thumbsucking.

question: Could develop.
answer: Let me see what you get, but don't jump--The New York Times thinks it's crazy Cubans.

question: OK, get on this W.House guy and do a better job then you did on McCord.
answer: I did all right on McCord.

question: Then how come the Associated Press were the ones found out that Mr. McCord is security coordinator for the Committee to Re-elect the President, otherwise known as CREEP?
answer: The head of security for the reelection of a Republican President got caught bugging the national offices of the Democrats? What the hell does that mean?

question: Mr. John Mitchell, the head of CREEP, says it means nothing. "...This man and the other people involved were not operating on either our behalf or with our consent. These is no place in our campaign or in the electoral process for this type of activity, and we will not forget it or condone it."
answer: You can't believe that.

question: As a rough rule of thumb, as far as I can throw Bronco Nagurski, that's how much I trust John Mitchell... What'd you get on W.House?
answer: Lotsa hints--

question: I can't sell hints to Simons-- --you called everyone you know? Call someone you don't know.
answer: Howard Hunt, please. Thanks, anyway--

question: Howard Hunt, please. Thanks, anyway--
answer: Charles Colson's wire.

question: Howard Hunt, please.
answer: Mr. Hunt isn't here just now.

question: Thanks, anyway.
answer: Have you tried Mullen and Company Public Relations? He works at Mullen and Company Public Relations as a writer. The number is 555-1313. I'm sorry I couldn't be more helpful.

question: Listen, forget it. Who's Charles Colson?
answer: I would liken your query to being in Russia half a century ago and asking someone, "I understand who Lenin is and Trotsky I got too, but who's this yokel Stalin?"

question: Who's Colson, Harry?
answer: The most powerful man in America is President Nixon, probably you've heard his name. The second most powerful man is Robert Haldeman. Just below him are a trio

question: Thanks, Harry. Know anything about Colson?
answer: Just that on his office wall there's a cartoon with a caption reading, "When you've got them by the balls, their hearts and minds will follow."

question: Hello, I'm Bob Woodward of the Washing Post and... Mullen and Company Public Relations? Could you tell me when you expect Mr. Hunt? He is? Hi, I'm Bob Woodward of the Post and-- I was just kind of wondering why your name and phone number were in the address books of two of the men arrested at Watergate? I'm sorry to bother you, Mr. Bennett, but we're doing some investigating of one of your employees, Howard Hunt. No secret at all. Hello, C.I.A. This is R.W. Woodward, of the Washington Post--get me Personnel-- Hi, I'm Bob Woodward of the Washington Post--and--what's that?--you've never heard of me?--I can't help that--you don't believe I'm with the Post?-- what do you want me to do, Madam, shout "extra--extra"?
answer: Whaddya got, whaddya got?

question: Hunt is Colson's man-- --that's Charles Colson, Nixon's special counsel-- --they both went to Brown University-- --Hunt worked for the C.I.A. till '70, and this is on deep background, the FBI thinks he's involved with the break-in.
answer: What else have you got?

question: According to White House personnel, Hunt definitely works there as a consultant for Colson. But when I called the White House Press office, they said he hadn't worked there for three months. Then the P.R. guy said the weirdest thing to me. "I am convinced that neither Mr. Colson nor anyone else at the White House had any knowledge of, or participation in, this deplorable incident at the Democratic National Committee."
answer: Isn't that what you'd expect them to say?

question: Here's the first take-- This is all of it, Harry. We have to talk. What the hell were you doing rewriting my story--
answer: --I sure couldn't hurt it, could I?--

question: --it was fine the way it was--
answer: --it was bullshit the way it was--

question: --I have to stand here and listen to the staff correspondent from Virginia?--
answer: --what have you been here, nine months?--I been in this business since I was sixteen--

question: --and you've had some fucking meteoric rise, that's for sure--by the time you turn forty you might be the head of the Montana bureau--
answer: --you only got the job because both you and Bradlee went to Yale--

question: --Bradlee went to Harvard--
answer: --they're all the same, all those Ivy League places--they teach you about striped ties and suddenly you're smart--

question: --I'm smart enough to know my story was solid--
answer: --mine's better--

question: --no way--
answer: --read 'em both and you'll see--

question: ...crap...
answer: Is mine better?

question: What is it about my writing that's so rotten?
answer: Mainly it has to do with your choice of words.

question: Carl?
answer: Yeah?

question: Fuck you, Carl.
answer: You heard? They put us both on the break-in thing. Simons liked the way we worked together. Listen, I'm sorry I said your story was bullshit.

question: It's OK; I'm sorry I called you a failure.
answer: Forget it, the main thing-- --did you call me a failure?

question: I was sure trying. All right, what do we know?
answer: Let me lay a little theory on you--

question: --I'm not interested in theory. What do we know? For example, Hunt's disappeared.
answer: Well, Barker tried to get blueprints of the Miami Convention Center and the air-conditioning system.

question: And McCord was carrying an application for college press credentials for the Democratic convention. The Times has got to be full of it-- it can't be crazy Cubans.
answer: What, though? It can't be the Republicans--he'd never allow something as stupid as this, not when he's gonna slaughter McGovern anyway.

question: Right. Nixon didn't get where he got by being dumb-- --listen, that was a Watergate question-- Hey?
answer: Hmm.

question: What do you think he meant, this particular incident? Were there others? How would we find out? You know anyone important?
answer: I lived here all my life, I got a million contacts, but they're all bus boys and bellhops. Someone inside the White House would be nice. Nothing at all you can remember?

question: I lived here all my life, I got a million contacts, but they're all bus boys and bellhops. Someone inside the White House would be nice. Nothing at all you can remember?
answer: Sorry. Now if it was Hunt you were interested in--

question: --Howard Hunt?
answer: Sure. Him I liked, he was a very nice person. Secretive too, traveled all over, but a decent man.

question: Any idea what he did?
answer: Oh, the scuttlebutt for awhile was he was investigating Kennedy--

question: --Teddy Kennedy?
answer: Sure. I remember seeing a book about Chappaquiddick on his desk and he was always getting material out of the White House Library and the Library of Congress and--

question: White House Library, please.
answer: Library.

question: Hi. Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post. I was just wondering if you remember the names of any of the books that Howard Hunt checked out on Senator Kennedy.
answer: I think I do remember, he took out a whole bunch of material. Let me just go see.

question: --what do you think?--
answer: --Hunt doesn't seem like your ordinary consultant.

question: Maybe a political operative of some sort--
answer: --a spy, you mean?

question: You think they are confidential? I don't know anything about how this town works, I haven't lived here a year yet.
answer: We need a sympathetic face. When did Hunt start at the White House?

question: July of '71.
answer: About the past year.

question: You do a lot of things when you're on a story. Can you believe we're actually doing this?
answer: That was fun. What now?

question: I met a Presidential aide once at a social occasion.
answer: And you haven't called him?--

question: You haven't got it. A librarian and a secretary say Hunt looked at a book. Not good enough.
answer: I was told by this guy at the White House that Hunt was investigating Teddy Kennedy.

question: How senior?
answer: You asking me to disclose my source?

question: Just tell me his title.
answer: I don't know titles.

question: I saw the flag signal--what's up?
answer: Nothing, that's the problem--the story's gone underground.

question: You thought I'd help out on specifics? I'll confirm what you get, try to keep you on the right track, but that's all. Are you guys really working? How much?
answer: I don't know maybe sixteen, eighteen hours a day--we've got sources at Justice, the FBI, but it's still drying up.

question: Then there must be something, mustn't there. Look, forget the myths the media's created about the White House-- the truth is, these are not very bright guys, and things got out of hand.
answer: If you don't like them, why won't you be more concrete with me?

question: Because the press stinks too--history on the run, that's all you're interested in. You come up with anything?
answer: John Mitchell resigned as head of CREEP to spend more time with his family. That doesn't exactly have the ring of truth. Howard Hunt's been found--there was talk that his lawyer had 25 thousand in cash in a paper bag.

question: Follow the money. Always follow the money.
answer: To where?

question: Go on.
answer: This man Gordon Liddy--he's going to be tried along with Hunt and the five burglars--we know he knows a lot, we just don't know what.

question: You changed cabs? You're sure no one followed you?
answer: I did everything you said, but it all seemed--

question: --melodramatic? Things are past that--remember, these are men with switchblade mentalities who run the world as if it were Dodge City.
answer: What's the whole thing about--do you know?

question: What I know, you'll have to find out on your own.
answer: Liddy--you think there's a chance he'll talk?

question: What's that?
answer: The fucking New York Times.

question: Goddamnit--
--I'm trying--
answer: --fifteen phone calls--

question: ---fifteen or more phone calls from the burglars in Miami to Gordon Liddy at CREEP--
answer: Why didn't we get that?

question: Christ, and I even know somebody at the phone company--
answer: --you do?--with access to records?

question: Why couldn't you have just dialed me from the office, Irwin?
answer: 'Cause I'm not calling out from the phone company anymore-- --I think the place is bugged.

question: So tell me about the Times article.
answer: What do you want to know?

question: No games, Irwin; give.
answer: My big civil rights buddy-- --boy, if John Mitchell was after your phone records, would you be screaming. What're you onto?

question: Something maybe big.
answer: And that makes anything you do OK, is that it?

question: Just tell me about the goddamn article.
answer: It was accurate, but I can't get a fuller listing for you--all Barker's phone records have been subpoenaed.

question: Who by?
answer: A Miami D.A. The guy doing the investigating is named Martin Dardis.

question: Irwin? I really feel bad, doing something like this--you know that, don't you?
answer: Don't give me any more of your liberal shit, OK, Carl?

question: at the water fountain on the 5th floor. He chews up a few Maalox tablets, notices BERNSTEIN steaming up.
answer: Harry, I just talked to a Miami investigator about Barker--

question: --so?
answer: I think it might be helpful if you'd send me to Miami.

question: I'm the one sent you to Toronto, Bernstein--
answer: --that was awhile ago--

question: --"I think it might be helpful if you'd send me to Toronto." That was your spiel then. "The Lifestyles of Deserters." I'm still waiting for it.
answer: Down to Miami and back--how much damage can I do?

question: You're the fella who forgot he rented a Hertz car, do I have to tell you they didn't forget to send us the bill? I can predict the next words you're gonna say
answer: Anyone but Bernstein.

question: Howard--
answer: --remember Toronto, Harry.

question: That was awhile ago.
answer: I don't get it--you were the one who wanted to fire him.

question: Yeah? Yes, this is Carl Bernstein. You're repossessing my bicycle? Listen, I'm sure I paid this month's installment, so why don't you check your records before you go around hassling people? Oh... Hannah, I never would have bothered you but I'm off to Miami and they're gonna take away my ten speed unless I get it straightened out fast.
answer: Where are your bills, Carl?

question: Oh, they're here. I'm keeping much better records now, Hannah. See?
answer: Carl, it's a jungle. I suggest you either pay this immediately or lay in a large supply of candles. You'd give a stranger the shirt off your back--except it wouldn't be paid for.

question: Hey... very tense.
answer: Lot of pressure at the Star. Carl, when we got married, you were four thousand dollars in debt; when we split, you were solvent. That may prove to be the outstanding single achievement of my life, and now look at this. How much did the damn bike cost?

question: Five hundred; six maybe.
answer: You're two months behind--you got enough to cover?

question: I think.
answer: Give me your checkbook then.

question: It's right under that pile.
answer: I thought you had to get to Miami.

question: There's always a later plane.
answer: You're a sex junkie, you know that, Carl?

question: Nobody's perfect. I'm glad you're out of it, Hannah-- you're a terrific reporter and I turned you into a bookkeeper.
answer: Aw baby, you can get it up... I just wonder if you'll ever be able to get it together.

question: seated perspiring on a hard bench in a stifling office. Outside Hi, it's me. I'm still here.
answer: I'm so glad.

question: I'd really like to see Mr. Dardis.
answer: And you will. But not now.

question: I called him from Washington. He's the one who asked me to be here at eleven in the morning.
answer: I told you, he had to go out on a case.

question: Could you reach Mr. Dardis by car radio?
answer: He is not in the car. Sorry.

question: Mr. Dardis does call in every so often?
answer: Well of course.

question: Good. Just tell him I was here, that I'm sorry I missed him-- Mr. Dardis' office, please.
answer: Mr. Dardis' office.

question: This is Mr. Tomlinson in the clerk's office. Could you come across the hall for a moment? We've got some documents your boss probably should see. Carl Bernstein's here to see you--I don't know why, but he seems angry-- Look, you've been jerking my chain all day. If there's some reason you can't talk to me--like the fact that you've already leaked everything to The New York Times--just say so.
answer: Listen, I've got a dinner--can't we do this tomorrow?

question: I'm on deadline.
answer: You want Barker's phone stuff or his money stuff?

question: Whatever.
answer: I'll never get out of here in time.

question: The telephone calls... we know about that.
answer: The rest is Barker's bank records. It's mostly the eighty-nine thousand in Mexican cashier's checks--

question: --yeah, that was in The Times this morning. What's this Dahlberg check?
answer: I never could figure just who this Dahlberg was. Think it might be anything?

question: --this should take only a minute, Mr. Dahlberg, but we're doing a follow- up on the break-in-- --and I was kind of curious about your check.
answer: ...check...?

question: The twenty-five thousand dollar one. The one with your name on it. In Bernard Barker's Florida account. Bernard Barker, the Watergate burglar--
answer: ...you're definitely doing a story...?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: I'm a proper citizen, I'm a decent man, I don't do anything that isn't decent or proper. I know I shouldn't tell you this... That twenty-five thousand dollars is money I collected for Nixon in this year's campaign.

question: I see. And how do you think it reached Miami?
answer: I don't know; I really don't. The last time I saw it was when I was in Washington. I gave it to the Finance department of the Committee to Re- Elect the President. How it got to that burglar, your guess is as good as mine.

question: --let me tell what happened when I was having lunch today at the Sans Souci--
answer: --correction--when you were drinking your lunch at the bar of the Sans Souci--

question: --this White House guy, a good one, a pro, came up and asked what is this Watergate compulsion with you guys and I said, well, we think it's important and he said, if it's so goddamn important, who the hell are Woodward and Bernstein?
answer: Ask him what he's really saying--he means take the story away from Woodstein and give it to his people at the National Desk--

question: --well, I've got some pretty experienced fellas sitting around, wouldn't you say so?--
answer: --absolutely--and that's all they do, sit sit sit--every once in a while, they call up a Senator, some reporting--

question: I don't believe the goddamn story, Howard, it doesn't make sense.
answer: It will, it just hasn't bottomed out yet, give it time.

question: Ben, Jesus, there are over two thousand reporters in this town, are there five on Watergate? Where did we suddenly get all this wisdom? Look--why would the Republicans do it? --my God, McGovern is self- destructing before our eyes--just like Muskie did, Humphrey, the bunch of 'em. Why would the burglars have put the tape around the door instead of up and down unless they wanted to get caught? Why did they take a walkie- talkie and then turn it off, unless they wanted to get caught? Why would they use McCord--the only direct contact to the Republicans?
answer: You saying the Democrats bugged themselves?

question: This is practically a high school reunion for us, Jane--I would have sprung for a classier place.
answer: Anyplace really public, they'd know about it--they know everything at the Committee, Carl--

question: --you don't really think you're being followed?
answer: This girlfriend of mine at the Committee, the other day she went back to the D.A. to tell the things the FBI didn't ask her. That night, her boss, he knew what she'd done. They control everything; that's how they know it all.

question: FBI too?
answer: You don't believe me? Well, I was working the weekend of the break-in and my God, all the executives were running around like crazy--you had to practically wait in line to use the shredding machine--and when the FBI came to investigate, they never even asked me about it.

question: If you don't like it down there, why don't you quit?
answer: I don't know what they'd do to me.

question: Hey, easy...
answer: We're a long way from high school, Carl... ...and I'm scared.

question: riding home on his bicycle. He gets to his building, starts lugging it up when-- I can help if you'll--
answer: --stay away from me, Carl!

question: My mistake, sorry. Get me John Mitchell, it's urgent. Can I speak to Martha Mitchell, please. I've met Mrs. Mitchell in Washington, I'm Bob Woodward of the Post and tell her-- I don't mind waiting.
answer: See her? Get anything?

question: For the paper, no; for us, plenty. I waited a long time and finally this big guy--I guess a bodyguard-- he left and I knocked and she remembered me, we talked awhile.
answer: And?--And?--

question: --she was panicked, Carl--every time I mentioned Watergate, you could tell.
answer: Were you eyebrow reading?

question: It was there. I just don't get it; a CREEP secretary being scared, that's one thing. But what does the wife of one of the most powerful men in America have to be afraid of...?
answer: Left up ahead.

question: Who's first?
answer: Alphabetically, on the CREEP phone list, Miss Helen Abbott of South George Street. Now hang your second right-- --this was my turf when I was a kid. I brought you over one street too many--go back and hang a left again. I don't get it... this really was my turf...

question: You're not a kid anymore.
answer: My first day as a copy boy I was sixteen and wearing my only grown-up suit--it was cream colored. At 2:30 the head copy boy comes running up to me and says, "My God, haven't you washed the carbon paper yet? If it's not washed by three, it'll never by dry for tomorrow." And I said, "Am I supposed to do that?" and he said, "Absolutely, it's crucial." So I run around and grab all the carbon paper from all the desks and take it to the men's room. I'm standing there washing it and it's splashing all over me and the editor comes in to take a leak, and he says, "What the fuck do you think you're doing?" And I said, "It's 2:30. I'm washing the carbon paper." (BERNSTEIN looks at

question: Hi. I'm Bob Woodward of the Washington Post and I hate to bother you at home-- No, I'm a reporter. I wanted to talk to you about the Committee to Re- Elect. You work there, Miss Abbott. Miss Abbott? We're from the Washington Post and we wanted to ask you some questions about the Committee.
answer: You had the Mighty Mo and the fries without gravy, right?

question: This is terrific work, if you like rejection.
answer: I never scared anyone before.

question: It's not us, they were scared before we got there. What do we know?
answer: Facts or theory?

question: Anything you've got.
answer: We know there's got to be something or they wouldn't be so panicked.

question: And that something's got to be more than just Hunt, Liddy, and the five burglars--those indictments are gonna be bullshit when they come down. What else do we know?
answer: I just wish we knew when someone would talk to us, that's all.

question: A friend at the Committee told us to contact you--
answer: We never reveal our sources, which is why you can talk to us.

question: It's safe, try it, you'll see.
answer: We understand your problem--

question: --you believe in the President, you wouldn't ever want to do anything disloyal.
answer: We appreciate your position--really.

question: At Yale once, they held an auction. There was this woman and her name was Lulu Landis. Her postcards came up for sale. She had 1400 postcards written to her and I'd never heard of her before but I knew I had to have those cards, I had to know why anyone would get so many messages. I paid sixty-five dollars for them... I got all crazy trying to work it out and first it was just a maze but then I found that her husband killed himself in Dayton, and once I had that, it all began to open, an evangelist had come to Dayton and his horses hit Lulu Landis at the corner of 13th and Vermillion and she was paralyzed. Permanently, and her favorite thing til then had been traveling and all her friends, whenever they went anyplace, they wrote her. Those cards, they were her eyes... Democrats?
answer: I hate both parties.

question: And I'm a Republican.
answer: (surprised, turns to

question: Sure.
answer: Who'd you vote for?

question: --omigod, you're from that place, you've got to go.
answer: Could I bum one of your cigarettes?-- --don't bother, I'll get it.

question: You've really got to go.
answer: Just let me get a match. But I want you to know that I understand why you're afraid--a lot of good people down there at the Committee are afraid. I'm really sorry for what you're being put through.

question: All those articles you people write-- where do you find that stuff?
answer: We don't tell anyone that. Which is why you can talk to us. And if we can't verify what you say someplace else, we don't print it. That's another reason you can relax.

question: I'm relaxed--light your cigarette.
answer: You were Hugh Sloan's bookkeeper when he worked for Maurice Stans at Finance, and we were sort of wondering, did you go work for Stans immediately after Sloan quit or was there a time lapse?

question: Please, yes, thank you. (he looks at the
answer: One minute but then--

question: --right, right, I've got to go. Why did you lie just then? I was just curious--you don't do it well, so I wondered. Have you been threatened, if you told the truth, is that it?
answer: ...No... never in so many words...

question: It's obvious you want to talk to someone--well, I'm someone. I'm not even going to put your name down. It's just so I can keep things straight. Start with the money, why don't you?
answer: How do you like it?

question: Everything, please.
answer: I won't be a minute.

question: The General Accounting report said there was a 350 thousand cash slush fund in Stans' safe. Did you know about that from the beginning?
answer: There are too many people watching me--they know I know a lot--

question: --it was all in hundreds, wasn't it?
answer: A lot of it was. I just thought it was sort of an all-purpose political fund--you know, for taking fat cats to dinner, things like that.

question: Could buy a lot of steaks, 350,000 dollars.
answer: I can't be positive that it was used for the break-in but people sure are worried.

question: Which people?
answer: The ones who could disburse the money.

question: Who were they?
answer: There were a group of them--I think five, I don't know their names.

question: I don't want to say anymore.
answer: It's awfully hot-- --and you haven't finished telling me about the money--

question: --omigod, there was so much of it, six million came in one two-day period-- six million cash, we couldn't find enough places to put it. I thought it was all legal, I guess I did, til after the break-in, when I remembered Gordon got so much of it.
answer: Gordon Liddy, you mean?

question: It was all so crazy--the day after the break-in he gave us a speech, bouncing up and down on his heels in that loony way of his--Gordon told us not to let Jim McCord ruin everything--don't let one bad apple spoil the barrel, he said. You just know that when Gordon Liddy's calling someone a bad apple, something's wrong somewhere. ...It's all so rotten... and getting worse... and all I care about is Hugh Sloan. His wife was going to leave him if he didn't stand up and do what was right. And he quit. He quit because he saw it and didn't want any part of it.
answer: Think Sloan's being set up as a fall guy for John Mitchell? Sometimes it looks that way.

question: If you guys... if you guys could just get John Mitchell... that would be beautiful...
answer: I couldn't believe what she told me. Eight cups of coffee worth.

question: I couldn't believe what she told me. Eight cups of coffee worth.
answer: Go on, go on--

question: --we've got to find out who the five guys are--the five with access to the slush fund--they were aware of the break-in.
answer: Then tomorrow's grand jury indictments will just be bullshit.

question: It goes very high--we've got to find out where--
answer: --we will--

question: --she was really paranoid, the bookkeeper.
answer: That happens to people. OK, go on.

question: How do you want to handle Sloan?
answer: You mean, who's going to play the mean M.P. and who's going to be the nice one? Whichever.

question: He's another Ivy Leaguer so he'll probably expect you to be understanding--might surprise him if you're not.
answer: You want me to be the bastard.

question: And I'll just shitkick in my usual way.
answer: To see Mr. Sloan.

question: --then again, maybe things are even worse than we've written--
answer: --they're worse. That's why I quit. Try and understand this. I'm a decent Republican. I believe in Richard Nixon. I worked in the White House four years--so did my wife. What happened on June 17 I don't think the President knew anything about. Some of his men I'm not so sure of.

question: Do you think the truth will come out at the trial?
answer: That's another of the things I'm not so sure of.

question: Because people at the Committee were told to lie to the prosecutors?
answer: We were never told flat out "Don't talk." But the message was clear.

question: To cover up?
answer: Well, they sure didn't ask us to come forward and tell the truth.

question: Well, they sure didn't ask us to come forward and tell the truth.
answer: Does "they" mean the White House?

question: As opposed to the Committee? The Committee's not an independent operation. Everything is cleared with the White House. I don't think that the FBI or the prosecutors understand that.
answer: The report on the cash in Maurice Stans' safe, the three hundred fifty thousand, that's true?

question: No. It was closer to seven hundred thousand.
answer: And as treasurer, you could release those funds?

question: When so ordered.
answer: We're not sure we've got all the guys who could order you, but we know there were five.

question: I won't talk about the other two.
answer: But they both worked at the White House?

question: I will not talk about the other two.
answer: Kalmbach--Nixon's personal lawyer.

question: Well, when Liddy came and asked for money for what turned out to be the break-in funds, I went to the safe and gave him--out of this whole fortune--I happened to give him the same hundreds he gave me--banks have to keep track of hundreds. If the money had been in fifties, or if I'd grabbed a different stack, there probably wouldn't have been any Watergate story.
answer: Ordinarily, though, what was the procedure?

question: Routine--I'd just call John Mitchell over at the Justice Department and he'd say "go ahead, give out the money."
answer: What happens when the baby comes?

question: We're moving. I've been looking for a job but it's been... hard. My name's been in the papers too much. Sometimes I wonder if reporters understand how much pain they can inflict in just one sentence. I'm not thinking of myself. But my wife, my parents, it's been very rough on them. I wish I could put down on paper what it's like--you come to Washington because you believe in something, and then you get inside and you see how things actually work and you watch your ideals disintegrate. The people inside, the people in the White House, they start to believe they can suspend the rules because they're fulfilling a mission. That becomes the only important thing-- the mission. It's so easy to lose perspective. We want to get out before we lose ours altogether.
answer: Look--five men controlled that slush fund as CREEP--three of them we've got, Mitchell, Stans, Magruder, and we're pretty sure of Kalmbach.

question: John Mitchell, please. Sir, this is Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post, and I'm sorry to bother you but we're running a story in tomorrow's paper that we thought you should have a chance to comment on.
answer: What does it say?

question: John N. Mitchell, while serving as US Attorney General, personally controlled a secret cash fund that--
answer: --jeeeeeeesus--

question: --fund that was used to gather information against the Democrats--
answer: --jeeeeeeesus--

question: --according to sources involved in the Watergate investigation. Beginning in the spring of 1971--
answer: --jeeeeeeesus--

question: --almost a year before he left the Justice Department--
answer: --jeeeeeeeeesus--

question: --to become President Nixon's campaign manager on March 1, Mitchell personally approved withdrawals from the fund--
answer: --all that crap, you're putting it in the paper? It's all been denied. You tell your publisher--tell Katie Graham she's gonna get her tit caught in a big fat wringer if that's published. Good Christ! That's the most sickening thing I ever heard.

question: Sir, I'd like to ask you a few--
answer: --what time is it?
Morning or night?

question: Night.
answer: Oh.

question: walking WOODWARD to the elevators.
answer: What do you think Mrs. Graham wants to see me for?

question: Maybe to fire you--since you two started on this story, the Post stock has dropped, what, 50 percent? And the word is some Nixon people are challenging her TV licenses. I'm not saying she's going on relief, but I don't think it's unreasonable for her to want to meet you.
answer: You think she wants us to ease up on the story?

question: I'm so glad you could come, Mr.--
answer: --I'm Woodward.

question: You know, the paper was my father's and my husband's when they were alive and I was thinking back a year or two ago when Ben called me and said he wanted to publish the Pentagon Papers the next day. The Times had already been stopped from publishing anymore of them and all my legal counsel said "don't, don't" and I was frightened but I knew if I said no, I'd lose the whole fifth floor. So we published, and that night, after I'd told Ben to go ahead, I woke up in the darkness and I thought, "Oh my Lord, what am I doing to this newspaper?" I woke up again last night with that same question. Are we right on this story?
answer: I think so.

question: Are you sure?
answer: No.

question: When will you be, do you think?-- when are we going to know it all?
answer: It may never come out.

question: Never? Please don't tell me never. Ben says you've found some wonderful sources.
answer: Some Justice Department lawyers and an FBI man, and some people from the Committee to Re-Elect, yes ma'am.

question: And the underground garage one. Would I know him?
answer: I couldn't say.

question: But it's possible.
answer: It is.

question: You've never told anyone who he is? But you'd have to tell me if I asked you. Tell me.
answer: I would, if you really ever wanted to know.

question: I really want to know. I wasn't serious. I have plenty of burdens to carry around, I don't need another. We're going to need lots of good luck, aren't we?
answer: Nobody ever had too much.

question: Goddamnit--
answer: --shit--

question: --we gotta top the Times--
answer: --I know, I know--

question: --if we could name the guys got the reports, we'd be ahead again--
answer: --shit, who do we know?--

question: --I know a lawyer at Justice--
answer: --has he got an ax?--

question: --almost every source we've used has been Republican, this guy's a card- carrying Democrat.
answer: Then he's got an ax. Call him anyway.

question: --I want you to shut up and listen to me--
answer: --I haven't said anything--

question: --for the first time I'm beginning to feel like a fucking reporter-- Woodward, I got a tip. A guy called me up with a tip-- --someone named Donald Segretti contacted a bunch of lawyers and asked them if they'd like to go to work with him screwing up the Democrats, dirty tricks, shit like that. The FBI knows about Segretti-- Howard Hunt made a bunch of phone calls to him--they interrogated him, but on account of Segretti wasn't involved with the break-in, they didn't follow through. But Segretti did a lot of traveling--he called these lawyers from different places, and he told them the Republicans knew what he was doing.
answer: How high up, which Republicans?

question: That's what we've got to find out, but Segretti went to Southern Cal. and so did a bunch of Nixon men--
answer: --Haldeman I know, who else?

question: Dwight Chapin, Nixon's appointments chief--he knew Segretti in school. Maybe I'm crazy, but this is the first time any of this starts to make sense. What were the three theories?
answer: The burglary was done by Cubans or Democrats or Republicans.

question: Now the reason no one believed the Republicans is because there wasn't any reason, they were so far ahead. But Segretti was talking to these other lawyers a year before the break- in.
answer: So maybe Watergate wasn't really about Watergate--maybe that was just a piece--

question: --because a year before, the Republicans weren't ahead, not in the polls, Muskie was running ahead of Nixon then. Before he self- destructed.
answer: If he self-destructed. Segretti criss-crossed the country over ten times in six months--and never stayed anyplace over a night or two. Switch to another station, huh? You're driving me crazy with that.

question: Segovia begged me for me secret but I said, "No, Andres, you'll have to try and make it without me."
answer: California, Illinois, Florida, New Hampshire--all the major Democratic primary states. Why does everything you play sound the same?

question: --'cause I only know four chords-- Donald Segretti?
answer: That's right.

question: I'm Carl Bernstein. My paper sent me out to see if I couldn't persuade you to go on the record.
answer: You can't.

question: Mind if I try? According to what we've been able to verify, you've been busy.
answer: I've got a lot of energy.

question: Listen--we know you're involved in this--we're going to get the story, why not help?
answer: They never told me anything except my own role--I had to find out the rest in the papers.

question: By "they" you mean...? By "they" you mean the White House, don't you? Your buddy from USC, Dwight Chapin-- he works for the White House.
answer: I know where Dwight works.

question: When did he hire you? Do you feel much about the things you did?
answer: I didn't do anything wrong.

question: Tell that to Muskie.
answer: Oh, maybe nickel and dime stuff.

question: During the Florida primary, you wrote a letter on Muskie stationery saying Scoop Jackson had a bastard child. You wrote another that said Hubert Humphrey was out with call girls.
answer: Sometimes it got up to a quarter maybe-- --off the record.

question: You wrote the Canuck letter--the one where you claimed Muskie slurred the Canadians.
answer: I didn't.

question: But you know who did.
answer: When you guys print it in the paper, then I'll know. I'm a lawyer, and I'll probably go to jail, and be disbarred, and what did I do that was so awful? None of it was my idea, Carl--I didn't go looking for the job.

question: Chapin did contact you then?
answer: Sure--off the record.

question: On the orders of Haldeman?
answer: I don't know anything about Haldeman, except, Dwight's frightened of him-- everybody's frightened of him--Christ, I wish I'd never gotten messed around with this--all I wanna do is sit in the sun; sit, swim, see some girls.

question: It gets interesting if it was Haldeman, because our word is that when Chapin says something, he's gotten the OK from Haldeman, and when Haldeman says something, he's gotten the OK from the President.
answer: Can't help you.

question: At USC, you had a word the this-- screwing up the opposition you all did it at college and called it ratfucking. Ever wonder if Nixon might turn out to be the biggest ratfucker of them all?
answer: What would you have done if you were just getting out of the Army, if you'd been away from the real world for four years, if you weren't sure what kind of law you wanted to practice, and then one day you got a call from an old friend asking you to go to work for the President of the United States...?

question: You asking would I have been one of the President's men? I would have been. alone in the underground garage. Tense, jumpy. He looks at his watch, paces around. It's all eerie as hell. Then, from the ramps, footsteps.
answer: My turn to keep you waiting. What's the topic for tonight?

question: Ratfucking.
answer: In my day, it was simply called the double cross. I believe the CIA refers to it as Mindfuck. In our context, it simply means infiltration of the Democrats.

question: I know what it means--Segretti wouldn't go on the record, but if he would, we know he'd implicate Chapin. And that would put us inside the White House.
answer: Yes, the little ratfuckers are now running our government.

question: Who?--be specific. How high up?
answer: You'll have to find that out, won't you.

question: The slush fund at CREEP financed the ratfucking, we've almost got that nailed down, so-- What?
answer: Did you change cabs? It didn't work, something moved there--

question: Who are you? Here. Forget your troubles and just be happy.
answer: I hope you noticed how coolly I behaved under the threat of discovery.

question: Do Justice and the FBI know what we know, and why the hell haven't they done anything about it?
answer: They know, but they focused on the burglary--if it didn't deal with the break-in, they didn't pursue it.

question: Why didn't they?--who told them not to?
answer: Someone with authority I'd imagine, wouldn't you? Don't you know what you're onto? Come on.

question: Mitchell knew then.
answer: Of course--my God, you think something this big just happens? The break-in and the cover up, of course Mitchell knew, but no more than Ehrlichman.

question: Haldeman too?
answer: You get nothing from me about Haldeman?

question: Why did they do all this for Chrissakes?--what were they after?
answer: Total manipulation. I suppose you could say they wanted to subvert the Constitution, but they don't think along philosophical lines.

question: Talk about Segretti--
answer: --don't concentrate on Segretti or you'll miss the overall scheme too.

question: There were more then.
answer: Follow every lead--every lead goes somewhere--

question: --the Canuck letter--was that a White House operation--
answer: --don't you miss the grand scheme too.

question: How grand?
answer: Nationwide--my God, they were frightened of Muskie and look who got destroyed--they wanted to run against McGovern, and look who they're running against. They bugged, they followed people, false press leaks, fake letters, they canceled Democratic campaign rallies, they investigated Democratic private lives, they planted spies, stole documents, on and on-- don't tell me you think this was all the work of little Don Segretti.

question: And Justice and FBI know all this?
answer: Yes, yes, everything. There were over fifty people employed by the White House and CREEP to ratfuck-- some of what they did is beyond belief.

question: Fifty ratfuckers directed by the White House to destroy the Democrats?
answer: I was being cautious. You can safely say more then fifty...

question: Do you guys know about the Canuck letter?
answer: Um-hmm. Why?

question: I just wanted to be sure you knew who wrote it.
answer: Tell him what you just told me.

question: Just than Ken Clawsen--he used to be a reporter here before he went to work for Nixon--I had him over for a drink a few weeks ago and he told me he wrote the Canuck letter. You did want to know, didn't you?
answer: You think we're being set up?--Christ, Deep Throat tells you last night that the letter came from inside the White House and up traipses Marilyn naming names.

question: Could have won him a fraternity paddle with a White House seal. God knows it worked. You claiming it was all a misunderstanding, Ken?
answer: Absolutely--Marilyn's gotten it totally wrong--

question: She's an awfully good reporter--I can't remember her getting too much wrong before, can you?
answer: That's a bullshit question, that's a question straight out of Wichita, Kansas.

question: Sorry, Ken; listen, one last thing
answer: Where? What do you mean, where?

question: Well, was it in a bar, her apartment, some restaurant--
answer: --I've completely forgotten where it was, except I know it wasn't her apartment.

question: Non denial-denial, Marilyn--
answer: For Chissakes, don't tell them I came to your place.

question: For Chissakes, don't tell them I came to your place.
answer: I already told them.

question: Oh, that's terrific, that's just so terrific, I'm thrilled you did that.
answer: I have a clear conscience.

question: I think that's him.
answer: Who?

question: Haldeman.
answer: Nah. Maybe.

question: What if I went up and introduced myself--think he'd slug me?
answer: Well, we are trying to ruin his life.

question: It's nothing personal, though.
answer: What's the matter?

question: Same as Magruder, I don't like it when they turn out to be human.
answer: I wish we were investigating Attila the Hun.

question: --we don't need it now, because tomorrow's story is about the FBI--
answer: --about how all you supposed experts really blew the whole investigation--

question: --you never knew Haldeman had control of the slush fund--
answer: --not about Haldeman-- --Jesus--

question: How many fucking sources they think we got?--
answer: --Deep Throat won't confirm--I never thought he was scared of anyone, but he's scared of Haldeman.

question: I know a guy in the Justice Department who was around the Grand Jury.
answer: --We got twenty minutes to deadline--

question: --what went wrong?--
answer: --for Chrissakes just tell that--

question: Woodward?
answer: Hmm?

question: What was the mistake? Do you think it's been rigged, all along the way, leading us on so they could slip it to us when it mattered? They couldn't have set us up better; after all these months our credibility's gone, you know what that means?
answer: Only everything...

question: --I know, I know, the pressure's off the White House and it's all back on the Post--
answer: --you've done worse than let Haldeman slip away, you've got people feeling sorry for him--I didn't think that was possible. A conspiracy like this-- the rope has to tighten slowly around everyone's neck. You build from the outer edges and you go step by step. If you shoot too high and miss, then everybody feels more secure. You've put the investigation back months.

question: We know that--and if we were wrong, we're resigning--were we wrong?
answer: You'll have to find that out, won't you?--

question: --I'm tired of your chickenshit games-- I don't want hints, I want what you know!
answer: It was a Haldeman operation--the whole business--he ran the money, but he was insulated, you'll have to find out how-- --wait-- --there's more...

question: walking up to his apartment house later that night. He sees, and then we see, BERNSTEIN, asleep at the front door. He comes awake as WOODWARD approaches. We gotta go see Bradlee--I'll fill you in in the car.
answer: You couldn't have told me over the phone?

question: We can't trust the phones, not anymore. Deep Throat says so.
answer: We can't talk inside either?
